Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Solar Physics at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics
Award.AbstractNarration:
This grant will continue an ongoing Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) Program at the Harvard-Smithsonian Center for Astrophysics (CfA), in which students will carry out individual research projects in solar physics under the supervision of CfA senior staff scientists and engineers for ten weeks during the summer. The student projects involve numerical modeling, data analysis from space missions currently being supported at the CfA, such as Hinode, SDO, IRIS, Wind, and DISCOVR, or engineering projects related to solar instrumentation being built at the CfA, depending on the students' interests and abilities. The target group of students consists of undergraduates in Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) disciplines, with a preference for underrepresented groups in STEM fields and students from small colleges where there are few research opportunities. The program will encourage minority student applications through contacts with other minority-serving internship programs on campus, recommendations from professional contacts at minority serving institutions, and a broad advertising campaign targeted at minority colleges and universities.

Since the projects are designed to be part of cutting edge solar physics research, student projects will frequently result in joint professional publications or presentations with their CfA mentors, providing undergraduates with valuable motivation and career development experiences. Since Solar Physics is taught at relatively few colleges and universities, this program provides an important service to the discipline. With its strong Space Weather component it has the double benefit to society of adding to our understanding of potential space hazards. Moreover, former participants of this program have reported that the exposure to professional research in a university environment has helped them to decide whether to continue their education in graduate school, and whether or not to pursue research as a profession. This site is supported by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Twenty-four students carried out individual research projects in solar physics under the supervision of staff scientists at the Harvard-Smithsonain Center for Astrophysics (CfA) for ten weeks during the summers of 2016, 2017 and 2018. The student projects involved data analysis from space missions currently being supported at the CfA ,such as Hinode, the Solar Dynamics Observatory, the Interface Region Imaging Spectrometer, and Wind, and hardware development for new instrumentation projects designed to observe the Sun from sounding rockets and airplanes.

In order to develop the students' practical skills needed for completion of their reserach, the students attended tutorials on computer programming and public speaking, as well as lectures in various topics in solar physics, such as space weather and the chromosphere.  Students gave final talks on their research that were open to everyone at the CfA, and most presented their research as a poster at a professional scientific conference.  

The scientific projects undertaken by the students all had significant scientific results, and there were four published papers that resulted from the projects, with several more in preparation. Some highlights are given below:

AIR-Spec instrumentation projects, summers 2016, 2017, and 2018. The AIR-Spec instrument is an infrared telescope designed to look at the outer atmosphere of the Sun during an eclipse. The telesope flies at a high altitude in a Gulfstream V airplane to minimize the effects of the atmosphere on the data. The first flight of the instrument was during the Great American Eclipse in August of 2017, and the second flight is planned during an eclipse in South America in July of 2019. REU students worked on various instrumentation projects related to the instrument, including the graphical user interface for the control systems for the first flight, the image stabilization system for the first flight, the alignment and calibration of the first AIR-Spec instrument, and the image stabilization system for the second flight. The first AIR-Spec eclipse flight successfully observed five infrared emission lines as a function of space and time in the solar corona, one of them for the first time. For the second flight, the AIR-Spec team has improved the sensitivity of the spectrograph by a factor of 20, and the team expects to be able to examine the drop off of the infrared emission as a function of height.

Identifying the Signatures of Magnetic Features on the Sun as Seen as a Star. The student used SDO/HMI data to determine the radial velocity of different features on the Sun, andf ound a measurable variation in the center-to-limb intensity-weighted velocity for these features. Characterizing the radial velocity of these solar features is important for removing variations in the radial velocity due to a star when looking for exoplanets.This project resulted in two published papers in refereed journals.

Coronal Mass Ejections and Shock Waves in EUV, White Light, and Radio. The student cataloged evidence for shock fronts using data in the extreme ultraviolet part of the spectrum from the Atmospheric Imaging Assemply telescopes on the Solar Dynmics Observatory. These features are important for understanding how particles are accelerated in the upper atmosphere of the Sun. Since these particles can interact with the Earth's magnetic field, causing disturbances in power grids and electric transmission lines, it is important to understand their origin.  This project, along with the work of two students from previous years of the program, resulted in a paper published in a refereed journal.

The evaluation of the program found that over the three years of the program, the students self reported a significant increase in skills such as data analysis, computer programming, theory, numerical modeling, and scientific communication.  Nearly all of the participants in the program were extremely likely to recommend the program to other undergraduates.
